newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil to draw $3.6 bln in capital flows - paper.
newsitem.headline: Brazil to draw $3.6 bln in capital flows - paper.

text.p: Brazil will attract $3.6 billion in capital flows between now and June, including $1.6 billion from the recent sale of a controlling stake in state mining firm CVRD, Gazeta Mercantil newspaper reported.

Quoting Central Bank International Affairs Director Gustavo Franco, Gazeta said $1.2 billion was also expected to enter Brazil from a global share offering by retail bank Unibanco. The offering was planned for the week of May 19.
Debt issues by Minas Gerais state electricity company Cemig were seen taking total capital flows between now and June to $3.6 billion, Franco said.
Capital flows have become an increasingly important indicator in Brazil due to concerns over the country's ability to finance a widening current account gap, expected to top $30 billion this year.

The government wants to be able to finance the gap with incoming funds so it does not have to dip into reserves, which it wants to keep at about $58 billion to, among other things, lend support for its reais currency.
